item.title: [WFLY-2027] EE Default DataSource is not working
item.description:
The EE spec states that a default datasource must be supplied under: java:comp/DefaultDataSource, and if none is specified by the @Resource or persistence.xml, it must be assumed:

EE 5.19
 
 
 
The Java EE Platform requires that a Java EE Product Provider provide a database 
in the operational environment (see Section EE.2.6, “Database”). The Java EE 
Product Provider must also provide a preconfigured, default data source for use by 
the application in accessing this database.
 
The Java EE Product Provider must make the default data source accessible to 
the application under the JNDI name java:comp/DefaultDataSource.
 
The Application Component Provider or Deployer may explicitly bind a 
DataSource resource reference to the default data source using the lookup element 
of the Resource annotation or the lookup-name element of the resource-ref
 
deployment descriptor element. For example,
 
@Resource(lookup="java:comp/DefaultDataSource")
 
DataSource myDS;
 
In the absence of such a binding, the mapping of the reference will default to 
the product's default data source.
 
For example, the following will map to a preconfigured data source for the 
product's default database:
 
@Resource
 
DataSource myDS;

This, isn't working however:

Feedback is welcome on whether JPA is required to use the default datasource... I read in this jira that it should be but why is it required? WFLY-2212 is the jira for that work.

Scott Marlow This blog is why I believe that's the case:

https://blogs.oracle.com/arungupta/entry/default_datasource_in_java_ee

I agree that is the spirit of what the blog conveys, however, it is ambiguous (IMO) how the blog describes what the container must do when it quotes the following part of the JPA 2.1 spec. I shouldn't feel ambiguous but I do, since this JPA requirement is not tied to EE7 (it was also in the JPA 2.0 spec).

It may also be that the EE 7 spec section quoted above was intended to also apply to JPA, however, I'm trying to separate wanting to do this change from what we are required by (EE/JPA) specification to do. Which is why I asked the question about why.

I agree that changing JPA to use the EE default DataSource, would be useful. However, others raised the concern that someone could easily forget to specify the datasource and find themselves (unexpectedly) using the wrong database. Anyway, please vote for WFLY-2212 if you want to see it completed (more likely to be WF9 at this point).

JPA 2.1 section 8.2.1.5 jta-data-source, non-jta-data-source

In Java EE environments, the jta-data-source and non-jta-data-source elements are used to specify the JNDI name of the JTA and/or non-JTA data source to be used by the persistence provider. If neither is specified, the deployer must specify a JTA data source at deployment or the default JTA data source must be provided by the container, and a JTA EntityManagerFactory will be created to correspond to it.

In Java SE environments, these elements may be used or the data source information may be specified
by other means—depending upon the requirements of the provider.

Also, the WildFly configuration (e.g. wf/standalone/configuration/standalone.xml or whichever config your using) contains:

<subsystem xmlns="urn:jboss:domain:jpa:1.1">
<jpa default-datasource="" default-extended-persistence-inheritance="DEEP"/>
</subsystem>

The jpa default-datasource can be specified, which does what your asking for (with the limitation that it is blank out of the box).

Is that blog post some kind of spec definition? I sincerely don't get the meaning of using a java:comp jndi name in a PU xml descriptor, which EE component namespace should it refer to, since PU doesn't have one? The spec reference above from Scott clearly defines what xml should be provided to delegate the data source choice to the container...

I agree with Eduardo Martins about java:comp/DefaultDataSource in the persistence.xml. The persistence unit can be referenced from EE components (e.g. via an @PersistenceUnit or @PersistenceContext or JNDI lookup or injection) but isn't part of a component.

I'm not completely sure how WFLY-2212 would need to be implemented but it might be as simple as changing the WildFly configuration to:

<subsystem xmlns="urn:jboss:domain:jpa:1.1">
<jpa default-datasource="java:jboss/datasources/ExampleDS" default-extended-persistence-inheritance="DEEP"/>
</subsystem>

Another WFLY-2212 implementation detail is that we would need a persistence unit hint to ignore the default datasource (OGM will not deploy with a datasource specified). Something like "wildfly.jpa.ignoredefaultdatasource".

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
 
<persistence xmlns="http://java.sun.com/xml/ns/persistence" version="1.0">
 
    <persistence-unit name="OGMTEST_PU">
 
    <provider>org.hibernate.ogm.jpa.HibernateOgmPersistence</provider>
 
    <properties>
 
         <property name="wildfly.jpa.ignoredefaultdatasource" value="true" />      
    </properties>
 
  </persistence-unit>
 
</persistence>

WFLY-2212 updated.

Antonio Goncalves Lincoln Baxter III Can I close this issue again?

Actually, I don't know if this was the case in JPA2.0, but notice that omitting any data-source results in a schema valid persistence.xml. If one of jta-data-source or non-jta-data-source were required, then I think the schema should show that, right?

If you still disagree, go ahead and close this

This requirement is not in the JPA spec actually, but in the Java EE 7. It states :

EE.5.19 - Default Data Source

The Java EE Platform requires that a Java EE Product Provider provide a database in the operational environment (see Section EE.2.6, “Database”). The Java EE Product Provider must also provide a preconfigured, default data source for use by the application in accessing this database.

The Java EE Product Provider must make the default data source accessible to the application under the JNDI name java:comp/DefaultDataSource.

The Application Component Provider or Deployer may explicitly bind a DataSource resource reference to the default data source using the lookup element of the Resource annotation or the lookup-name element of the resource-ref deployment descriptor element. For example,

@Resource(lookup="java:comp/DefaultDataSource")
 
DataSource myDS;

In the absence of such a binding, the mapping of the reference will default to the product's default data source.
For example, the following will map to a preconfigured data source for the product's default database:

@Resource
 
DataSource myDS;

Lincoln Baxter III See Scott reference to JPA spec, not providing a datasource is valid and is how the PU indicates that it should be the container to select a datasource. At WFLY-2212 I example how to update the container's data source selection process, to pickup the EE default datasource if the JPA subsystem config does not defines one.

Antonio Goncalves java:comp is a namespace that exists in the scope of a particular EE component, such as an EJB. Each EE component has its own java:comp context, except for components in a WAR, these share a single one.
PUs are not EE components, for instance you may have one in a standalone jar or in EAR lib jar, in such cases which of the java:comp contexts in Wildfly would the PU xml refer to?
You have two ways for using Wildfly default datasource in a PU, you either don't provide a datasource (jta and non jta), which will work in every Java EE platform implementation, or you provide the JNDI name configured for the default datasource in the EE subsystem xml.

PS: please note that until WFLY-2212 is solved, to use the portable way you need to configure the default datasource yourself in the JPA subsystem configuration, just copy the jndi name in the EE subsystem configuration.

Antonio, I agree with you, that JPA does not require the EE default data source to be used. EE 7 does require one to be available but only at the EE component level which doesn't apply to persistence unit definitions for reasons that I stated above (persistence unit is not part of a EE component but is instead used by EE components).

Eduardo Martins, I don't think that there is a portable way as JPA doesn't require a default datasource feature to be implemented. Unless someone can state otherwise (with a reference to the JPA spec section that points out that I am in error), I think we should treat WFLY-2212 as an extension. This is a minor point but others will look at this jira to help them understand more about using a default datasource with jpa. I think we are otherwise in agreement.

Scott Marlow I'm not a JPA expert, but in your previous quote:

JPA 2.1 section 8.2.1.5 jta-data-source, non-jta-data-source
In Java EE environments, the jta-data-source and non-jta-data-source elements are used to specify the JNDI name of the JTA and/or non-JTA data source to be used by the persistence provider. If neither is specified, the deployer must specify a JTA data source at deployment or the default JTA data source must be provided by the container...

Eduardo Martins The quoted JPA specification is not from EE7/JPA 2.1. There was no "default JTA data source" at the EE product level in earlier EE versions. However, JBoss AS7 did introduce a JPA level default data source (which WildFly 8.0.0 also has), that is the "default JTA data source".

What do you mean with not from EE7/JPA 2.1? Java EE 7 spec includes JPA 2.1, and within JPA 2.1 spec there is that section 8.2.1.5 which you quoted, I confirmed that now. Doesn't that says in Java EE the container is responsible for providing a default data source if the persistence.xml has no "jta-data-source" and no "non-jta-data-source"?

Excellent question, I mean that the above (JPA spec) text was added to the earlier JPA 2.0 specification, which went into EE 6 (before the default data source concept was introduced into the EE 7 spec later).

JPA 2.0 spec (EE 6) section 8.2.1.5 jta-data-source, non-jta-data-source

In Java EE environments, the jta-data-source and non-jta-data-source elements are used to specify the global JNDI name of the JTA and/or non-JTA data source to be used by the persistence provider. If neither is specified, the deployer must specify a JTA data source at deployment or a JTA data source must be provided by the container, and a JTA EntityManagerFactory will be created to correspond to it.

These elements name the data source in the local environment; the format of these names and the ability to specify the names are product specific.

In Java SE environments, these elements may be used or the data source information may be specified by other means—depending upon the requirements of the provider.

Forget everything prior to EE 7, there is JPA 2.1 8.2.1.5 saying the EE container provides a default datasource, and thus that's what we need to do in Wildfly 8. That truly reads to me as the real portable way for a PU to apply for a EE platform default datasource.

Now there is nothing in the specs saying it has to be the same default datasource as java:comp/DefaultDataSource for an EJB, I guess it's fine to keep the feature in JPA config to define a specific one, but I think it would be nice to have these in sync by default, which is what my patch at WFLY-2212 "starts".

I still think there are no reasons for keeping this issue open, section EE 5.19 that is in the issue descriptor is about @Resource and <resource-ref/>, not persistence-unit.xml, and every java:comp context instance in Wildfly has java:comp/DefaultDataSource bound...

Regarding forgetting about earlier EE releases, I disagree about that line of understanding the current EE 7 requirements. We can't go back in time and re-invent what was intended by earlier EE/JPA spec versions (the JPA intent back in the EE 6 days was not for the container to use the EE product level default data source as there was no such thing). To me, this part of the discussion only determines what is an EE 7 specification requirement for the (JPA) container.

I see no reason to keep this jira open either and no one has given a strong enough "EE compliance" counter argument for this jira to be open.

No one has of yet argued against WFLY-2212 being fixed, which is encouraging for those that want it.

Its my understanding that Java EE 7 require a default data source to be available. It could map to whatever the underlying JDBC resource might be.

I asked Linda DeMichiel (spec lead for JPA and Java EE 7 platform) about the default data source and here is what she said:

– cut here –
Java EE 7 does require that a platform product provide a default
data source. This is covered in section EE.5.19 of the Platform
spec:

"The Java EE Platform requires that a Java EE Product Provider
provide a database in the operational environment (see Section
EE.2.6, “Database”). The Java EE Product Provider must also provide
a preconfigured, default data source for use by the application in
accessing this database.

"The Java EE Product Provider must make the default data source
accessible to the application under the JNDI name
java:comp/DefaultDataSource."
– cut here –

It does not matter what java:comp/DefaultDataSource point to, an in-memory database or MySQL or some other data source. But the main idea behind all this was to ensure more seamless OOTB experience where developers do not have to configure an additional item in order to get started.

Arun,

Please see earlier comments in this jira about JPA not being required to use the EE default datasource (java:comp.DefaultDataSource). I don't particularly care if I am right or wrong but can only go by the facts (JPA spec wording about a default data source is pre-EE7.)

Did Linda specifically point out that JPA persistence units would be able to find the default data source via java:comp/DefaultDataSource? From an EE point of view, it would be good to clarify exactly what portable applications can expect.

Scott
